prompt:
Prompt: We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, “Laughter is the shortest distance between two people.” Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

Given the prompt, write an average essay that has inconsistent but minimal spelling and grammar errors, but it lack coherent structure and organization, is minimally focused, and has the style of a fourth or fifth grader's writing, .
rubric:
6": "The writing is exceptionally clear, focused, and interesting. It holds the reader's attention throughout. Main ideas stand out and are developed by strong support and rich details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced, in-depth explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are compelling and move the reader through the text easily. The writing is characterized by: effective, perhaps creative, sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; a strong, inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a strong, satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates deep commitment to the topic, and there is an exceptional sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an effective level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); an exceptionally strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
            "5": "The writing is clear, focused and interesting. It holds the reader's attention. Main ideas stand out and are developed by supporting details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are strong and move the reader through the text. The writing is characterized by: effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; an inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates commitment to the topic, and there is a sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an appropriate level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); a strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
            "4": "The writing is clear and focused. The reader can easily understand the main ideas. Support is present, although it may be limited or rather general. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose; clear main idea(s); supporting details that are relevant, but may be overly general or limited in places; when appropriate, resources are used to provide accurate support; a topic that is explored / explained, although developmental details may occasionally be out of balance with the main idea(s); some connections and insights may be present; content and selected details that are relevant, but perhaps not consistently well-chosen for audience and purpose. Organization is clear and coherent. Order and structure are present, but may seem formulaic. The writing is characterized by: clear sequencing and paragraph breaks; an organization that may be predictable; a recognizable, developed beginning that may not be particularly inviting; a developed conclusion that may lack subtlety; a body that is easy to follow with details that fit where placed; transitions that may be stilted or formulaic; organization which helps the reader, despite some weaknesses. A voice is present. The writer seems committed to the topic, and there may be a sense of "writing to be read." In places, the writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. The reader may glimpse the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction in places; liveliness, sincerity, or humor when appropriate; however, at times the writing may be either inappropriately casual or personal, or inappropriately formal and stiff.",
            "3": "The reader can understand the main ideas, although they may be overly broad or simplistic, and the results may not be effective. Supporting detail is often limited, insubstantial, overly general, or occasionally slightly off-topic. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose and main idea(s); predictable or overly-obvious main ideas; or points that echo observations heard elsewhere; or a close retelling of another work; support that is attempted, but developmental details are often limited, uneven, somewhat off-topic, predictable, or too general (e.g., a list of underdeveloped points); details that may not be well-grounded in credible resources; they may be based on cliches, stereotypes or questionable sources of information; difficulties when moving from general observations to specifics. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writer's commitment to the topic seems inconsistent. A sense of the writer may emerge at times; however, the voice is either inappropriately personal or inappropriately impersonal. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",
            "2": "Main ideas and purpose are somewhat unclear or development is attempted but minimal. The writing is characterized by: a purpose and main idea(s) that may require extensive inferences by the reader; minimal development; insufficient details; irrelevant details that clutter the text; extensive repetition of detail. The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
            "1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader.
essay:
One time my friend and I were at the park and we saw a dog chasing a squirrel. It was so funny because the squirrel was running really fast and the dog was barking like crazy. My friend and I couldn't stop laughing at the silly scene.

We tried to catch our breath and calm down, but then we noticed a little kid trying to feed bread to a group of ducks. The ducks were all squawking and flapping their wings, and the kid was chasing after them with the bread. It was so hilarious to watch the chaos unfold.

After that, we sat down on a bench and talked about all the funny things we had just seen. We kept giggling and snickering as we remembered the dog, the squirrel, the ducks, and the kid. It was like we were sharing a secret language of laughter that only we understood.

That day, I learned that laughter really is the shortest distance between two people. It brought my friend and me closer together as we shared in the joy of those silly moments. I realized how important laughter is in a relationship, whether it's a friendship or something more. It creates a bond that can't be broken, no matter how many ducks try to steal your bread.

essay: One time me and my frend were playing at da park. We were swinging really high on teh swings and then I fell off and landed in a puddle of mud. It was so funny becuz I was all dirty and wet. My frend started laffing so hard that he fell off his swing too! It was so silly. Then we were both covered in mud and laffing so much that we couldn't stop. We had to go home and take a bath and our moms were mad at us but we just kept laffing. Laffter is da best thing ever and it brings people together. It's so importent to have fun and not take things too siriusly. I love laffter and it makes every day better. The end.

prompt:
Prompt: Resilience is the ability to bounce back from adversity, challenges, or setbacks. It involves staying strong, flexible, and optimistic even in difficult times. A resilient person is not easily discouraged and can find ways to move forward despite obstacles. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
rubric:
3": "Tells a story with ideas that are clearly focused on the topic and are thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced. Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience. Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
            "2": "Tells a story with ideas that are somewhat focused on the topic and are developed with a mix of specific and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are logically sequenced. Adequate command of language, including effective word choice and clear sentences, supports the writer's purpose and audience. Adequate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
            "1": "Tells a story with ideas that are minimally focused on the topic and developed with limited and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are weak. Limited use of language, including lack of variety in word choice and sentences, may hinder support for the writer's purpose and audience. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
            "0": "Ideas are not focused on the task and/or are undeveloped. No organization evident. Ineffective use of language for the writer's purpose and audience. Ineffective use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation.
essay:
One of the most inspiring examples of resilience that I have witnessed was when my best friend, Emily, faced a series of setbacks during her sophomore year of high school. Despite the challenges she encountered, she remained strong, flexible, and optimistic throughout the entire ordeal.

It all started when Emily was diagnosed with a chronic illness that required her to undergo frequent medical treatments and take medication daily. This news was devastating for her, as it meant that she would have to miss a lot of school and extracurricular activities. Despite the physical toll that the illness took on her body, Emily refused to let it define her. She continued to attend classes whenever she could, often participating remotely through video calls with her teachers and classmates.

As if dealing with her illness wasn't challenging enough, Emily also experienced academic setbacks during this time. Due to her frequent absences, she fell behind in her coursework and struggled to keep up with assignments. However, instead of giving up, Emily sought help from her teachers and classmates, working tirelessly to catch up on missed work and improve her grades. She attended tutoring sessions, stayed after school for extra help, and spent countless hours studying at home. Her determination and perseverance paid off, as she was able to raise her grades and finish the semester successfully.

In addition to her health and academic struggles, Emily also faced personal challenges during this time. She felt isolated from her friends and peers, as she missed out on social events and gatherings due to her illness. However, instead of withdrawing further into herself, Emily reached out to her friends and family for support. She confided in them about her struggles and fears, and they rallied around her, offering words of encouragement and comfort.

Despite the numerous obstacles that she faced, Emily never lost hope or gave up. She remained resilient in the face of adversity, always looking for ways to move forward and overcome the challenges that came her way. Her strength, flexibility, and optimism were truly inspiring, and her ability to bounce back from setbacks with grace and determination left a lasting impact on everyone around her.

In conclusion, resilience is a powerful trait that can help us navigate life's challenges with grace and strength. Emily's story is a testament to the importance of staying strong, flexible, and optimistic in the face of adversity. Her ability to bounce back from setbacks and continue moving forward, despite the obstacles in her path, serves as a reminder that we all have the power to overcome adversity and emerge stronger on the other side.

essay:
One day, my friend Sara showed lots of resilience. She had a big spelling test at school, and she was really nervous about it. She studied really hard all week, but when the test came, she forgot how to spell some of the words.

Sara felt really upset and wanted to give up, but instead, she took a deep breath and asked her teacher if she could retake the test. Her teacher said yes, but Sara only had one more chance to get it right.

Sara didn't give up. She studied even harder for the retake, and when the day came, she spelled every word correctly. She was so proud of herself for not giving up and working hard to overcome the challenge.

I was really impressed by Sara's resilience that day. It showed me that even when things get tough, you can still push through and come out stronger on the other side. Sara's determination and positive attitude inspired me to be more resilient too.

One time my frend had a really hard challenge. He had to run a race at skool and he sprained his ankle! It was soo bad and evrione thot he wuld give up. But he didnt! He kep runnin and he was struglin but he dint stop. He was strong and brave and he diddent give up.

My frend is reelie resiliant becaus he did this hard thing and he dint give up. He did his best even tho it was hard. I like my frend becaus he is strong and brave like a super hero. Hed did a good job even tho he got hurt. He is the best frend evr and I am proud of him.

prompt:

Do only one of the following: write a story about a time when you were patient OR write a story about a time when someone you know was patient OR write a story in your own way about patience.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.

essay:
Patience is a quality that not everyone possesses. It requires understanding, tolerance, and the ability to endure difficult situations without complaining. I have always admired people who demonstrate patience, as I believe it is a key characteristic of true strength and resilience.

One particular incident comes to mind when I witnessed someone I know exhibit remarkable patience. It was during a family vacation to Disneyland, and we were all excited to experience the rides, shows, and meet our favorite characters. However, as luck would have it, we found ourselves stuck in a long line for the most popular ride in the park.

While everyone around us was growing increasingly frustrated and impatient, my aunt remained calm and composed. She kept a smile on her face and entertained us with stories from her childhood, distracting us from the long wait. Despite the scorching sun and endless line, she never once complained or showed any signs of irritation.

As we finally reached the front of the line after what felt like an eternity, I asked my aunt how she managed to stay so patient throughout the ordeal. She simply replied, "Life is full of unexpected delays and obstacles. It's how we choose to react to them that defines our character. Patience is a virtue that helps us navigate through life's challenges with grace and dignity."

Her words stuck with me long after that day. I realized that true patience is not just about waiting for something to happen, but about how we handle the waiting. It is about finding peace in the midst of chaos, and maintaining a positive attitude in the face of adversity.

Since then, I have tried to embody my aunt's example of patience in my own life. I have learned to pause, take a deep breath, and remind myself that everything happens in its own time. Patience has taught me to trust the process, even when the outcome is uncertain.

In conclusion, patience is a valuable trait that can help us navigate through life's challenges with grace and perseverance. Whether it is waiting in line at Disneyland or facing a difficult situation, the ability to remain calm and understanding is a strength that should be celebrated. As I continue to cultivate this virtue in my own life, I am grateful for the lesson my aunt taught me that day.

prompt:
Prompt: Write about patience. Being patient means that you are understanding and tolerant. A patient person experience difficulties without complaining. Do only one of the following: write a story about a time when you were patient OR write a story about a time when someone you know was patient OR write a story in your own way about patience.

Given the prompt, write an average essay that has inconsistent but minimal spelling and grammar errors, but it lack coherent structure and organization, is minimally focused, and has the style of a fourth or fifth grader's writing, .
rubric:
3": "Tells a story with ideas that are clearly focused on the topic and are thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced. Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience. Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
            "2": "Tells a story with ideas that are somewhat focused on the topic and are developed with a mix of specific and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are logically sequenced. Adequate command of language, including effective word choice and clear sentences, supports the writer's purpose and audience. Adequate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
            "1": "Tells a story with ideas that are minimally focused on the topic and developed with limited and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are weak. Limited use of language, including lack of variety in word choice and sentences, may hinder support for the writer's purpose and audience. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
            "0": "Ideas are not focused on the task and/or are undeveloped. No organization evident. Ineffective use of language for the writer's purpose and audience. Ineffective use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation.
essay:
Patience is when you wait for something without getting mad. I am patient when I have to wait in line at the store or when my little brother is taking a long time to tie his shoes. Sometimes it's hard to be patient, but it's important to be kind and understanding.

One time, my mom showed a lot of patience. She had to wait for a long time at the doctor's office. We were sitting in the waiting room for what felt like forever. I was getting bored and fidgety, but my mom just sat there calmly reading a book. She didn't complain or get mad, even though we had been waiting for a really long time.

I asked her how she could be so patient, and she told me that sometimes you just have to accept that things take time. She said that getting mad wouldn't make the wait any shorter, so it was better to be patient and make the best of the situation.

Seeing my mom be so patient really taught me a lesson. It made me realize that patience is a good quality to have. It helps you stay calm and keep a positive attitude, even when things aren't going your way.

So now, whenever I have to wait for something, I try to remember my mom's example and be patient. It's not always easy, but I know that being patient is the right thing to do. It makes me feel like a better person, and it helps me handle difficult situations with grace.

Being patient might be hard sometimes, but it's worth it in the end. It helps you stay calm and understanding, even when things are tough. I'm glad I learned about patience from my mom, and I'll always try to be patient in everything I do.

essay: One time I had to be patient was when my mom was busy cooking dinner and I wanted a snack. I waited and waited and counted to a million before she was finally done. My mom was very understanding and I didn't complain at all. Instead, I helped set the table and waited quietly. When dinner was finally ready, I was so happy that I waited patiently. Being patient is important because it shows that you are not selfish and can wait for things to happen on their own time. Being patient can be hard sometimes, but it is worth it in the end. I think being patient is a good quality to have and I will try to be patient in the future too.

prompt:
Prompt: We all understand the benefits of laughter. For example, someone once said, “Laughter is the shortest distance between two people.” Many other people believe that laughter is an important part of any relationship. Tell a true story in which laughter was one element or part.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
rubric:
6": "The writing is exceptionally clear, focused, and interesting. It holds the reader's attention throughout. Main ideas stand out and are developed by strong support and rich details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced, in-depth explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are compelling and move the reader through the text easily. The writing is characterized by: effective, perhaps creative, sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; a strong, inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a strong, satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates deep commitment to the topic, and there is an exceptional sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an effective level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); an exceptionally strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
            "5": "The writing is clear, focused and interesting. It holds the reader's attention. Main ideas stand out and are developed by supporting details suitable to audience and purpose. The writing is characterized by: clarity, focus, and control; main idea(s) that stand out; supporting, relevant, carefully selected details; when appropriate, use of resources provides strong, accurate, credible support; a thorough, balanced explanation / exploration of the topic; the writing makes connections and shares insights; content and selected details that are well-suited to audience and purpose. The organization enhances the central idea(s) and its development. The order and structure are strong and move the reader through the text. The writing is characterized by: effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; the organizational structure fits the topic, and the writing is easy to follow; an inviting beginning that draws the reader in and a satisfying sense of resolution or closure; smooth, effective transitions among all elements (sentences, paragraphs, ideas); details that fit where placed. The writer has chosen a voice appropriate for the topic, purpose, and audience. The writer demonstrates commitment to the topic, and there is a sense of "writing to be read." The writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: an appropriate level of closeness to or distance from the audience (e.g., a narrative should have a strong personal voice, while an expository piece may require extensive use of outside resources and a more academic voice; nevertheless, both should be engaging, lively, or interesting. Technical writing may require greater distance.); a strong sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader and of how to communicate the message most effectively. The reader may discern the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction; a sense that the topic has come to life; when appropriate, the writing may show originality, liveliness, honesty, conviction, excitement, humor, or suspense.",
            "4": "The writing is clear and focused. The reader can easily understand the main ideas. Support is present, although it may be limited or rather general. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose; clear main idea(s); supporting details that are relevant, but may be overly general or limited in places; when appropriate, resources are used to provide accurate support; a topic that is explored / explained, although developmental details may occasionally be out of balance with the main idea(s); some connections and insights may be present; content and selected details that are relevant, but perhaps not consistently well-chosen for audience and purpose. Organization is clear and coherent. Order and structure are present, but may seem formulaic. The writing is characterized by: clear sequencing and paragraph breaks; an organization that may be predictable; a recognizable, developed beginning that may not be particularly inviting; a developed conclusion that may lack subtlety; a body that is easy to follow with details that fit where placed; transitions that may be stilted or formulaic; organization which helps the reader, despite some weaknesses. A voice is present. The writer seems committed to the topic, and there may be a sense of "writing to be read." In places, the writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. The reader may glimpse the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction in places; liveliness, sincerity, or humor when appropriate; however, at times the writing may be either inappropriately casual or personal, or inappropriately formal and stiff.",
            "3": "The reader can understand the main ideas, although they may be overly broad or simplistic, and the results may not be effective. Supporting detail is often limited, insubstantial, overly general, or occasionally slightly off-topic. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose and main idea(s); predictable or overly-obvious main ideas; or points that echo observations heard elsewhere; or a close retelling of another work; support that is attempted, but developmental details are often limited, uneven, somewhat off-topic, predictable, or too general (e.g., a list of underdeveloped points); details that may not be well-grounded in credible resources; they may be based on cliches, stereotypes or questionable sources of information; difficulties when moving from general observations to specifics. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writer's commitment to the topic seems inconsistent. A sense of the writer may emerge at times; however, the voice is either inappropriately personal or inappropriately impersonal. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",
            "2": "Main ideas and purpose are somewhat unclear or development is attempted but minimal. The writing is characterized by: a purpose and main idea(s) that may require extensive inferences by the reader; minimal development; insufficient details; irrelevant details that clutter the text; extensive repetition of detail. The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
            "1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader.
essay:
Laughter truly has a way of bringing people closer together. I experienced this firsthand during a family vacation to the beach last summer. 

My parents, my younger sister, and I decided to take a break from our busy lives and spend a week relaxing by the ocean. It was the perfect opportunity for us to unwind and bond as a family. 

One day, we decided to rent paddleboards and go out into the water. My dad, who likes to think of himself as a pro at all water sports, was the first one to get on his board. He confidently stood up and started paddling away, but within seconds, he lost his balance and fell face-first into the water. 

My sister and I burst out laughing at the sight of our dad flailing around in the water, trying to get back on his paddleboard. Even my mom couldn't contain her laughter as she attempted to rescue him. 

Despite the initial embarrassment, my dad couldn't help but join in on the laughter. We spent the rest of the afternoon sharing stories and jokes, creating memories that we would cherish for years to come. 

That day at the beach taught me the importance of laughter in fostering strong relationships. It allowed us to let go of our inhibitions and connect on a deeper level. Laughter truly is the shortest distance between two people, breaking down barriers and bringing us closer together.

essay:
Once upon a time, me and my best friend Sarah had a sleepover at her house. We were having so much fun playing games and talking about all kinds of stuff. Then, we decided to make some popcorn and watch a funny movie.

The movie was so hilarious! We couldn't stop laughing at all the silly jokes and funny scenes. At one point, Sarah accidentally spilled her drink all over herself and we both started cracking up. We were laughing so hard that we couldn't breathe!

After the movie was over, we were still giggling about how messy Sarah got. We decided to have a dance party in her living room and we were busting out all kinds of silly dance moves. We were laughing so much that our stomachs hurt!

Before we knew it, it was getting late and we had to go to bed. As we lay in our sleeping bags, we couldn't stop laughing about all the fun we had that night. It was the best sleepover ever!

The next morning, we woke up with smiles on our faces, still remembering all the laughter from the night before. We knew that no matter what, we would always have each other to share funny moments with. Laughter truly is the best medicine for any friendship!

            "4": "The writing is clear and focused. The reader can easily understand the main ideas. Support is present, although it may be limited or rather general. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose; clear main idea(s); supporting details that are relevant, but may be overly general or limited in places; when appropriate, resources are used to provide accurate support; a topic that is explored / explained, although developmental details may occasionally be out of balance with the main idea(s); some connections and insights may be present; content and selected details that are relevant, but perhaps not consistently well-chosen for audience and purpose. Organization is clear and coherent. Order and structure are present, but may seem formulaic. The writing is characterized by: clear sequencing and paragraph breaks; an organization that may be predictable; a recognizable, developed beginning that may not be particularly inviting; a developed conclusion that may lack subtlety; a body that is easy to follow with details that fit where placed; transitions that may be stilted or formulaic; organization which helps the reader, despite some weaknesses. A voice is present. The writer seems committed to the topic, and there may be a sense of "writing to be read." In places, the writing is expressive, engaging, or sincere. The writing is characterized by: a suitable level of closeness to or distance from the audience; a sense of audience; the writer seems to be aware of the reader but has not consistently employed an appropriate voice. The reader may glimpse the writer behind the words and feel a sense of interaction in places; liveliness, sincerity, or humor when appropriate; however, at times the writing may be either inappropriately casual or personal, or inappropriately formal and stiff.",
            "3": "The reader can understand the main ideas, although they may be overly broad or simplistic, and the results may not be effective. Supporting detail is often limited, insubstantial, overly general, or occasionally slightly off-topic. The writing is characterized by: an easily identifiable purpose and main idea(s); predictable or overly-obvious main ideas; or points that echo observations heard elsewhere; or a close retelling of another work; support that is attempted, but developmental details are often limited, uneven, somewhat off-topic, predictable, or too general (e.g., a list of underdeveloped points); details that may not be well-grounded in credible resources; they may be based on cliches, stereotypes or questionable sources of information; difficulties when moving from general observations to specifics. An attempt has been made to organize the writing; however, the overall structure is inconsistent or skeletal. The writing is characterized by: attempts at sequencing and paragraph breaks, but the order or the relationship among ideas may occasionally be unclear; a beginning and an ending which, although present, are either undeveloped or too obvious (e.g., "My topic is..."; "These are all the reasons that..."); transitions that sometimes work. The same few transitional devices (e.g., coordinating conjunctions, numbering, etc.) may be overused; a structure that is skeletal or too rigid; placement of details that may not always be effective; organization which lapses in some places, but helps the reader in others. The writer's commitment to the topic seems inconsistent. A sense of the writer may emerge at times; however, the voice is either inappropriately personal or inappropriately impersonal. The writing is characterized by: a limited sense of audience; the writer's awareness of the reader is unclear; an occasional sense of the writer behind the words; however, the voice may shift or disappear a line or two later and the writing become somewhat mechanical; a limited ability to shift to a more objective voice when necessary; text that is too short to demonstrate a consistent and appropriate voice.",
            "2": "Main ideas and purpose are somewhat unclear or development is attempted but minimal. The writing is characterized by: a purpose and main idea(s) that may require extensive inferences by the reader; minimal development; insufficient details; irrelevant details that clutter the text; extensive repetition of detail. The writing lacks a clear organizational structure. An occasional organizational device is discernible; however, the writing is either difficult to follow and the reader has to reread substantial portions, or the piece is simply too short to demonstrate organizational skills. The writing is characterized by: some attempts at sequencing, but the order or the relationship among ideas is frequently unclear; a lack of paragraph breaks; a missing or extremely undeveloped beginning, body, and/or ending; a lack of transitions, or when present, ineffective or overused; a lack of an effective organizational structure; details that seem to be randomly placed, leaving the reader frequently confused. The writing provides little sense of involvement or commitment. There is no evidence that the writer has chosen a suitable voice. The writing is characterized by: little engagement of the writer; the writing tends to be largely flat, lifeless, stiff, or mechanical; a voice that is likely to be overly informal and personal; a lack of audience awareness; there is little sense of "writing to be read"; little or no hint of the writer behind the words. There is rarely a sense of interaction between reader and writer.",
            "1": "The writing lacks a central idea or purpose. The writing is characterized by: ideas that are extremely limited or simply unclear; attempts at development that are minimal or nonexistent; the paper is too short to demonstrate the development of an idea. The writing lacks coherence; organization seems haphazard and disjointed. Even after rereading, the reader remains confused. The writing is characterized by: a lack of effective sequencing and paragraph breaks; a failure to provide an identifiable beginning, body and/or ending; a lack of transitions; pacing that is consistently awkward; the reader feels either mired down in trivia or rushed along too rapidly; a lack of organization which ultimately obscures or distorts the main point. The writing seems to lack a sense of involvement or commitment. The writing is characterized by: no engagement of the writer; the writing is flat and lifeless; a lack of audience awareness; there is no sense of "writing to be read"; no hint of the writer behind the words. There is no sense of interaction between writer and reader; the writing does not involve or engage the reader.
essay:
I like to play with my friends at recess. We run around and play tag. One time, my friend Sally fell down and she got mud on her pants. It was really funny because she looked silly with mud on her butt.

We laughed so much that our teacher had to tell us to be quiet. But we couldn't stop laughing. Then, our teacher slipped on a banana peel and fell down too! We laughed even more because she looked even sillier with banana on her butt.

After that, we all had to go to the principal's office. We couldn't stop giggling and the principal was very mad at us. We had to promise not to laugh anymore, but it was so hard because everything seemed so funny.

In the end, we all got detention for laughing too much. But it was worth it because I had so much fun with my friends. Laughter is really important in a relationship because it brings people together and makes everything more fun. I can't wait to laugh with my friends again tomorrow.

prompt:
Prompt: Resilience is the ability to bounce back from adversity, challenges, or setbacks. It involves staying strong, flexible, and optimistic even in difficult times. A resilient person is not easily discouraged and can find ways to move forward despite obstacles. Write a story about a time when you or someone you know demonstrated resilience in the face of a challenge.

Given the prompt, write an excellent essay that has no spelling or grammar mistakes, is very focused and organized very well, has advanced but appropriate vocabulary choice, and has the style of a tenth grader's writing.
rubric:
3": "Tells a story with ideas that are clearly focused on the topic and are thoroughly developed with specific, relevant details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are clear and logically sequenced. Command of language, including effective and compelling word choice and varied sentence structure, clearly supports the writer's purpose and audience. Consistent, appropriate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
            "2": "Tells a story with ideas that are somewhat focused on the topic and are developed with a mix of specific and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are logically sequenced. Adequate command of language, including effective word choice and clear sentences, supports the writer's purpose and audience. Adequate use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
            "1": "Tells a story with ideas that are minimally focused on the topic and developed with limited and/or general details. Organization and connections between ideas and/or events are weak. Limited use of language, including lack of variety in word choice and sentences, may hinder support for the writer's purpose and audience. Limited use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation for the grade level.",
            "0": "Ideas are not focused on the task and/or are undeveloped. No organization evident. Ineffective use of language for the writer's purpose and audience. Ineffective use of conventions of Standard English for grammar, usage, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation.
essay:
Resilience is a quality that is often tested in times of adversity. It is the ability to bounce back from challenges and setbacks, and to remain strong and optimistic in the face of difficulties. I have seen this quality demonstrated by my friend, Sarah, in a moment of crisis that tested her resilience.

Last year, Sarah was faced with a major setback when she lost her job unexpectedly. She had been working at the same company for several years and had built her career there. Losing her job was a huge blow to her self-esteem and confidence. However, instead of giving up or feeling sorry for herself, Sarah chose to see this setback as an opportunity for growth and change.

Sarah spent the first few days after losing her job feeling down and uncertain about the future. But soon, she picked herself up and started looking for new job opportunities. She updated her resume, reached out to her network for job leads, and went on multiple interviews. Despite facing rejection and disappointment along the way, Sarah remained determined and focused on finding a new job.

After several weeks of searching, Sarah finally landed a new job in a different field. While the job was not exactly what she had envisioned for herself, Sarah saw it as a stepping stone towards her long-term career goals. She embraced the opportunity with enthusiasm and worked hard to excel in her new role.

Sarah's resilience in the face of adversity was truly inspiring to me. Despite the challenges she faced, she remained strong, flexible, and optimistic throughout the process. She did not let the setback define her or hold her back from pursuing her goals. Instead, she used it as a learning experience and a chance for personal growth.

In the end, Sarah's resilience paid off. She not only found a new job but also gained a sense of confidence and resilience that will serve her well in any future challenges that come her way. Through her example, Sarah has taught me the importance of staying strong and hopeful in the face of adversity, and never giving up on my dreams.

essay:
Resilience is when you don't give up even when things are hard. One time, my friend Sarah showed a lot of resilience when she got a bad grade on her math test.

Sarah is really good at math usually, but this time she didn't do so well. She was really sad and upset about it. She thought about giving up and not trying anymore.

But then she remembered that she is a strong person who can handle challenges. She decided to study harder and ask for help from her teacher. She practiced more and worked really hard to understand the math problems.

Even though it was tough, Sarah kept going and didn't give up. She stayed positive and believed in herself. And you know what? The next math test she took, she got a much better grade!

I was so proud of Sarah for showing resilience and not letting one bad grade bring her down. She proved that if you keep trying and stay strong, you can overcome any challenge that comes your way.
